comments.raw_text:
Currently, if the user goes to Preferences/Privacy and selects "Firefox will (Never remember history)", their Firefox session goes into a perpetual private browsing state where "Stop Private Browsing" is disabled in the menu.  This is not intuitive behavior.  All the user has done is disabled history, and Private Browsing is a concept that we treat differently, with different language and implications.  It's a concept the user who disabled history may not even be  familiar with.  Disabling even entering private browsing creates an unexpected mode around the history preference, and effectively prevents the user from entering private browsing mode.  Just because two states - private browsing and disabled history - have similar effects does not mean we should conflate these concepts to the user.

This problem will become worse when we visually style private browsing mode differently and isolate it to a window rather than a session.

Expected behavior: When the user disables remembering history, that preference is all that should change.  The user is not in private browsing mode at this point - their history is just not being remembered.  They can still enter private browsing mode while in this state.

Actual behavior: Not remembering history is treated like a perpetual private browsing mode, even though the user has never explicitly enabled private browsing mode
comments.creator: jboriss@mozilla.com

comments.raw_text:
(In reply to comment #0)
> Expected behavior: When the user disables remembering history, that
> preference is all that should change.  The user is not in private browsing
> mode at this point - their history is just not being remembered.  They can
> still enter private browsing mode while in this state.

This doesn't match the implementation model - when that pref is set, the user *is* permanently in private browsing mode (that's how we ensure that their data isn't saved). If we let the user go out of private browsing mode, then Firefox's behavior won't match "never remember history" setting that they've chosen, and as you say it's not obvious that the two are related in that way. So it's not just a matter of re-enabling the menu item.
comments.creator: gavin.sharp@gmail.com

> user *is* permanently in private browsing mode (that's how we ensure that
> their data isn't saved). If we let the user go out of private browsing mode,
> then Firefox's behavior won't match "never remember history" setting that
> they've chosen, and as you say it's not obvious that the two are related in
> that way. So it's not just a matter of re-enabling the menu item.

It's unfortunate that the two are intrinsically linked implementation-wise, but we really do need two states here: private browsing mode with (eventually) the style change, and a never-remember-history-pref-set mode.  Even if the latter is implemented as kind of style-less private browsing mode, this isn't how we should be messaging the state to the user.  If the user set that preference to not remember history, they're only signing up for not remembering history, and the UI really needs to reflect that.

comments.raw_text: The Preferences window UI does explain that the pref in question is more than just not remembering history.  If what you're asking for is for that pref to *only* not remember the history and not do everything else which happens in the PB mode, then that maps to a new implementation of that pref.  But that kind of depends on how we define "history".  IIRC Faaborg wanted that term to include all of the stuff covered by the PB mode, not just the "places history".  Is that still a valid statement?
